name: ORGANIZATIONAL BEHAVIOR

values.comments:
Management 238 is the standard undergraduate course in Organizational Behavior.  The course deals essentially with the management of people at work. It examines the individual employee in his organizational environment, as well as the organization itself.  Topics range from motivation, leadership groups all the way to organization structure, culture, human resources and organizational change.  The course develops some themes in which these topics become relevant -- for example the networking organization and diversity at the workplace.  Students should expect to conduct group projects involving actual fieldwork and might be asked to give a presentation in class. 

Many students claimed that this course was the “best class at Penn.”  It taught the “basics of organizational behavior and also how to apply analytic thought in a managerial context.”  Class meetings are “fun and meaningful.”  

Students really liked Professor Grant, one saying he was “one of the most sincere, genuine professors” and another saying he was the “single best professor in Wharton.”  His lectures are extremely engaging and concepts are widely applicable.  He clearly “cares for his class and students, making each class well structured, engaging and full of useful and applicable knowledge.”  Almost every student commented on Professor Grant’s “stellar teaching,” emphasizing his receptiveness to questions and “willingness to connect with students.”

Students did not mention too much about the workload. One said it was the “second least stressful class” they had taken at Penn.  “You don’t have to worry at all about your grade here.” Most students strongly recommended this class to everyone. This class is not required of Wharton students and can be used to satisfy Concentration requirements. Prerequisites for this course are MGMT 100 & MGMT 101.
